description: Demolition of existing dwellinghouse and garage and replacement with six bedroom detached dwellinghouse and swimming pool
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within 3 years from the date of this decision.Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990.  (As amended)

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a)  materials for all external finishes and window frames (including their manufacturer's specification, dimensions, colour and texture).Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of any development on site, a Construction Management Plan detailing the following:(a)  Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b)  Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c)  Signing system for works traffic.(d)  Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(e)  Means of enclosure of the site.(f)  Wheel washing equipment.(g)  The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(h)  The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.shall be submitted to the planning authority for written agreement. The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the details and measures approved as part of the construction management plan, which shall be maintained throughout the entire construction period.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a)  refuse storage facilities in accordance with the requirements of the Residential Design SPD, 2013 (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a)  boundary treatment, including walls, fences and gates (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the walls of the dwelling houses hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason:  In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town & Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order, 1995 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions (including porches or dormer windows) to the dwelling houses shall be erected within the curtilage.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the proposed side elevation windows at first floor level shall be non-opening and glazed with obscure glass to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale and shall be permanently maintained thereafter as non-opening and obscure glazed. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to Level 3. Reason: To safeguard the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties from overlooking and loss of privacy in accordance with POlicy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments, including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The approved Basement Impact Assessment (dated November 2019) shall be adhered to throughout the excavation and construction works.Reason: In the interests of amenities of surrounding residential occupiers during the construction of the development and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments, including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.In response to neighbour notification, 2 letters of objection have been received from a single property raising the following concerns:- The submitted Daylight/Sunlight Assessment is flawed;- Loss of daylight/sunlight;- Undue sense of unclosure- Mutual loss of privacy- Distress caused by construction works and damage to neighbouring propertyOfficer Note: Party Wall issues relating to property damage would be a civil matter and not for consideration as part of the current planning application. With reference to potential distress, noise disturbance and loss of privacy arising from the temporary construction phase, Officers do not consider that there would be any signficant or lasting adverse impact on neighbouring amenity arising from the construction works associated with the proposed domestic extension. It is also noted that the Local Authority has powers under The Control of Pollution Act 1974 to enforce against statutory nuisance, were a statutory nuisance to occur.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed extension would not strictly accord with the Residential Design SPD guidance in relation to depth, it is considered that it would appear subordinate and proportionate to the existing dwelling and would be of an appropriate design that would relate well to the existing building. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is noted that a similar proposal was previously refused on this site due to an unacceptable loss of daylight to a neighbouring habitable room. The current scheme has replaced the previously refused parapet roof (approximately 3.3m in height) along the shared boundary with adjoining No. 88 with a mono-pitched roof with an eaves height of 2.2m along the shared boundary. It is noted that permitted development for boundary treatment would allow a 2m high fence along the boundary. Within this context the proposed eaves height along the shared boundary is considered to be relatively modest and is considered sufficient to ensure no significant overbearing impact or undue sense of enclosure to No. 88. The submitted Daylight and Sunlight Report indicates that while there would be a loss of daylight to habitable room windows at No. 88 it would not be significant as the window would retain at least 0.9 times its former value with the new development in place. The orientation of the properties and position of the extension is such that there would be no signficant impact on sunlight to No. 88. In relation to No. 84, the set-back from the boundary and relatively modest depth is sufficient to ensure no significant adverse impact on neighbouring amenity.The concerns raised in the submitted letters of objection about the robustness of the submitted Daylight and Sunlight Report are noted. However, Officers consider that the submitted Assessment provides an acceptable level of detail commensurate with the scale of the proposed development to assess the impact on neighbouring habitable rooms (a bathroom is not considered to be a habitable room).Overall, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The site falls within fluvial Flood Zone 2. Officers are satisfied with the mitigation and flood resilience measures proposed by the applicant and consider that there would be no significant adverse impact on fluvial flood risk subject to the aforementioned measures being secured by planning condition.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.3 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. - Flood risk assessmentWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the modest scale and siting of the proposed development, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Five neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on flooding.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed first floor side extension would measure approximately 2.3 metres in height to the eaves with a split gable end roof, approximately 3.5 metres in depth and 1.7 metres in width and would be set back 5 metres from the front elevation. The proposed roof form would relate well to the host property and would not exceed the ridge of the existing main roof, in accordance with Policy Guidance 36. Officers note that the ground floor is proposed to site flush with the front elevation of the main dwelling. Overall, it is considered that the proposed extensions would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition and would relate well to the host dwelling.Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  No. 142 and No. 146 Somerset Avenue are the principal properties to be considered in relation to amenity. With regards to No. 142 Somerset Avenue there would be no adverse impact due to the nature and siting of the proposals in relation to the existing situation. Due to the limited depth of the proposed first floor side extension there would be no unacceptable loss of light to neighbouring habitable rooms of No.146 Somerset Avenue. Officers note that no windows or openings are proposed to the flank walls. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts.Officer Comment: The Flood Risk Form submitted by the applicant indicates that the proposed extension would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would not be required as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Seven neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highwaysWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed first floor side extension would measure approximately 5.8 metres in height to the eaves with a split gable end roof, approximately 7.2 metres in depth and 2.5 metres in width and would be set in 1 metre from the neighbouring boundary. Officers note that the side extension has not been set back from the front elevation but note that similar extensions have previously been appoved at several addresses on Elgar Avenue including 129 Elgar Avenue (16/16593/HOU granted 27/10/2016) and 139 Elgar Avenue (05/16273/FUL granted 27/05/2005). The proposed roof form would relate well to the host property as extended and would not exceed the ridge of the existing main roof, in accordance with Policy Guidance 36. It is considered that the proposed extensions would appear proportionate and subordinate to the host dwelling.Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  With regards to the amenities of the neighbouring properties, Officers note the provision of a window at first floor level on the eastern flank elevation but, overall, there is a reduction in the number of openings compared to the existing dwelling and the applicant would use obscured glazing (this would be secured by condition should permission be granted). Overall it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.  Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate two off street car parking spaces, therefore the proposal would comply with  Policies DM9 and DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
